text: uh hi everyone thank you for a nice
introduction uh my name is David Stevens
and I'm from a media company in Sweden
called TV4 and I'm here to talk to you
guys about the work that we do at TV4
and the Finnish equivalent MTV3 to
enable developer autonomy through
infrastructure as code and policy as
code in order to operate through DevOps
teams uh this presentation is going to
be a bit of a whirlwind tour of the work
we do so strap on in and get comfortable
um I'm going to start by talking briefly
about who TV4 and MTV are because while
these are household names in the Nordic
market they are we don't operate at all
outside the Nordic so most of you
probably haven't heard of us uh then I'm
going to talk about the work that I've
done to help developers write
infrastructures as code using CDK for
Terraform and finally talk about the
work I've done to help developers write
good infrastructures code using OPA or
open policy agent because there's a key
distinction between these two things so
first starting off TV4 and MTV these are
the two largest commercial TV channels
in Sweden and Finland they have a
massive outreach to the local markets
and they are sibling companies that are
currently both owned by Telia company
which is why we collaborate very closely
using a shared infrastructure platform
and large amounts of shared code in the
codebase um the two TV channels in
addition to broadcasting TV also have
streaming services with millions of
users so we are quite heavily embracing
the digital transformation as they call
it in a fancy way um but basically we've
uh transitioned largely to digital
streaming from linear
broadcasting and all of this is deployed
on AWS with a bunch of different
microservices our usage of open tofu uh
is completely standardized and
completely centralized we use it
exclusively to manage the cloud
resources that we have in AWS in total
we have more than around 300 different
open tofu projects this is different
microservices that we operate internally
and this adds up to about 1,400
workspaces when you cover both brands
and different development environments
staging environments things like that uh
in total there's about 18 different
teams that operate their own
infrastructure and these are teams
across every discipline so at TV4 the
front-end team with Nex.js developers
are in charge of operating their
infrastructure the same way that a data
science team might be or a backend
development team all of them own their
own infrastructure because ultimately
they are the team that has the best
understanding of what they need um but
of course this introduces a lot of
challenges because there's quite a lot
of knowledge gap for some of these
people so that's something we need to
work on in total we have around 80
different active open tofu users and
very many of these are consultants the
result of this is that onboarding and
making that process as fast and as
efficient as possible is really critical
to the way that we operate because that
onboarding process happens all the time
and is quite
expensive and all of this is supported
by my team a cloud infrastructure team
of five people of which two focus on
platform engineering so getting this
scaling to work where two people are
able to support 80 people also requires
a lot of special
attention and in particular it requires
us to help the developers because the
big problem that we see in a lot of
organizations is that it's very easy to
try to force developers to embrace the
way that us infrastructure people are
used to working the approach that we've
taken at TV4 and MTV is flipping this on
its head we try to adapt the way that
you work with infrastructure to be a
better match with the way that
developers are used to
working and you might be wondering why
we need to do something like this
because obviously we all like open tofu
this is a room full of people who would
travel across the world to go to an open
tofu convention um but sometimes it's
good to remember that some people might
not be quite as comfortable with
infrastructures code especially when you
force these teams to operate their own
infrastructure
and the key in this uh the key thing
that is the most difficult thing about
open tofu for beginners is that
infrastructure itself is incredibly
difficult this is unavoidable uh if
you've looked at any public cloud
infrastructure provider there's a
million different configuration options
that you can set and there's a million
different services that you can combine
in exponentially more ways so this part
is unavoidable there's no way for us to
reduce the actual complexity of the
cloud so what we're instead going to be
focusing on is reducing the complexity
of everything else and one such thing is
HDL itself this is the configuration
language that you use to declaratively
write uh open tofu and while it's quite
nice once you get used to it it can be
unintuitive for people who are used to
imperative programming languages and
quite a big like change of mindset
especially when you consider the meta
arguments uh that come in like count
dynamic for each things like this as
soon as open tofu tries to be more
imperative in a way it becomes quite
confusing this is something that Mike
covered in his talk earlier this morning
uh so if you attended that he had half
of examples that I was planning on
bringing up uh and one such example is
also the way that conditionals work in
open tofu uh because in HCL uh consider
that you're writing a module or
something like that and you have certain
resources that you may or may not want
to enable depending on some input value
a conventional way to do this would be
to have a count meta argument that
checks some input variable and if it's
true you set it to one otherwise you set
it to zero um this works but it's really
difficult to keep track of once you
start writing a very large module uh and
I'm sure that anyone who has tried
looking at something like the AWS
modules or something like that the
actual source code to it you would get
overwhelmed with trying to keep track of
what is enabled in what circumstance
and this doesn't just affect people who
write modules it doesn't just affect us
the platform engineers it also affects
the developers who might want different
configuration for a development
environment as opposed to a production
environment another big pain point that
we bump into quite often is stringly
typed providers um because while
Terraform and open tofu itself is
strongly typed and the provider schema
can tell you that this field is supposed
to be a number this field is supposed to
be a string sometimes the provider will
just say this field is supposed to be a
string that contains a big JSON blob of
data and I'm sure we all have our
favorite or least favorite examples of
this uh mine in particular we heavily
use AWS ECS as our container runtime and
they have this one resource called ECS
task definitions uh in which there's a
field called container definitions which
for Kubernetes folks is essentially the
pod specification and it has on the
order of maybe 50 different inner fields
uh that all have different type
information that is completely not typed
in the provider it's up to you to make
sure that you keep track of everything
and we bump into issues with this all
the time uh there are also a lot of
providers where validation happens at
apply time instead of plan time and this
really slows down the developer feedback
loop um because they would open a pull
request try to get their code out uh go
through this whole review process and
then apply their code only to find that
their load balancer in AWS has a name
that is longer than 32 characters and it
crashes and we have to start over and do
everything
again uh finally um sharing constants
and state can be a bit difficult in open
tofu uh constants could be things like
uh trusted IP networks like your office
network or things like that as far as I
can tell the best way to do this is to
have some kind of uh shared module that
only defines a bunch of outputs and then
you read those outputs but this becomes
quite tricky to handle uh I'm seeing
some nodding of audience so I think some
people might have bumped into things
like this before but most of
all open tofu and htl is just yet
another thing to learn and this adds up
and every single thing that you need to
learn during an onboarding process means
that the onboarding is
longer so what we chose to do instead is
to try to meet the developers where they
are and we do this using the cloud
development kit for Terraform and Open
Tofu it's named up because it's a
hashore project and um this is basically
a way that you can write your open tofu
in Typescript which then gets compiled
to HTL or JSON um yeah good that's
somewhat visible um developers don't
need to learn new syntax when you do
this they only have to focus on
semantics like focus on the actual
concepts of infrastructures code and not
need to worry about how you would
actually define things in HTL examples
of this would be for loops for loops
work exactly like you expect you can do
for loops over providers even if you
don't have open tofu 1.9 uh using this
which then would get compiled down to
just separate statements for each
provider think of it like the most
complex templating language you can
imagine basically um so for loops work
like ex like you expect except when they
don't i don't really have time to get
into that uh if statements work the way
you expect uh bindings get automatically
generated for every single Terraform
provider and every single Terraform
module even if you have custom in-house
modules or providers uh you just run a
single command and it will introspect
the schema of your open tofu provider
and generate bindings for this so that
you can use everything uh it also comes
with a CLI that enables things like
stack dependency ordering where if you
have a reference from one workspace to a
different workspace the CLI will
actually be able to identify this and
make sure that the workspaces are
applied in the correct order or
destroyed in the correct order uh that
destroy thing has been a pretty large
pain point for us because sometimes the
easiest way to fix destroying things in
the wrong order is to reapply the thing
you just destroyed uh which always seems
a bit
bad and this is also supported in uh
Python Go C or Java if you prefer those
languages over TypeScript but for us
TypeScript is kind of the least common
denominator that all developers
understand in our organization and it
also provides some nice features with
typing that you can
do so you might be asking yourself isn't
that just Open Tofu but with extra steps
because
ultimately all of the code that you
write in Typescript is going to get
compiled to Open Tofu and the thing
that's actually going to be executed
against your cloud environments is Open
Tofu you can't actually do anything in
CDKTF that you can't do in Open
Tofu but there are a host of benefits
that you get instead by using this as a
really powerful templating language the
first of these is that all of the meta
arguments that can be hard to understand
are replaced with familiar constructs
for most developers you can also create
arbitrarily strong uh type wrappers over
stringly typed providers this is
something that we do quite extensively
internally to patch over uh things that
we wish for different than a provider
you can also run arbitrary JavaScript
functions during compilation this might
sound scary um but it's quite powerful
actually because it allows you to do
things like uh configure remote backends
or providers or things like that in a
more dynamic way based on for instance
the file path that your configuration is
in and perhaps most significantly it
enables you to write your modules as
JavaScript packages instead of being
regular HTL modules once you do this you
can start working with object-oriented
modules instead of just having
composition uh so you could for instance
have a cloudfront uh CDN with a VPC
origin which inherits from the
CloudFront CDN with a generic origin uh
allowing you to just restructure the way
that you do uh your modules and it
becomes a lot easier to keep track of
things uh it's completely trivial to
share constants because you can just
export anything in JavaScript and you
can even do custom functions in modules
this way um because in your JavaScript
package you could export whatever you
want including functions and this is
actually something that's closed that's
not planned in open tofu because it
breaks compatibility with HTL uh quite
extensively so that's kind of an
interesting thing that you could be
doing
and another interesting thing you can do
is that you can actually abstract away
the Tyraform block itself and provider
configuration so one thing we do very
extensively uh developers never have to
think about which backend they're using
or the name of a workspace or anything
of that sort all of that is
automatically set by our uh cdtf library
which they
use so let's have a quick look at how
such a library might look um what you
see here is just a super simple class uh
which extends the base class Terraform
stack which is basically a terraform
workspace um in within the like circle
pieces that you have here uh I have a
remote backend configuration that uses
some environment variables to determine
the host name that you're going against
it names the workspace based on the path
of the current file all of this is of
course made up we don't do exactly this
but we do something quite similar uh and
it leads to developers not having to
think about these things and it just
happening uh we also have a for loop uh
in the second red circle that initiates
different AWS providers in a somewhat
dynamic way so this class in its
constructor it take constructor it takes
a list of AWS accounts that you would
like to deploy to and then it
instantiates AWS providers for each of
the accounts that you have provided uh
assuming different roles and setting
different default tags based on the
inputs that you have passed to the class
uh this is quite a powerful abstraction
and allows you to standardize things a
lot easier across your organization for
instance we were able to introduce uh
global cost allocation tags across every
single workspace in our organization by
just asking them to update version of
our helper library and then it would

have uh you can also export whatever you

different account ids or something like

JavaScript so like I was mentioning
earlier here we're actually generating
the workspace name based on a file path
this JavaScript could also be like a web
request it could be literally whatever
you
like uh and all of this would of course
be done during compile time so this is
not something that's being executed when
you're actually running your apply so
you will be able to see all of this in
your git version control
history and if we look at the usage of
this library in this case we have a
simple stack that um instantiates the
library that we just created for the
development and the production account
and uh for each account uh that we have
chosen uh it creates an EC2 instance for
this so this is a for loop over
providers uh for each loop so similarly
to what you nowadays are able to do in
open tofu
1.9 uh you're also able to provide

definitions earlier uh in this example
I've created a subclass of the task
definition that works the same way as a

uh this allows you to actually get error
messages in your editor uh if you have a
typo in this particular case uh it's
extra scary because that particular typo
would not only not be caught during
apply time it wouldn't be um it wouldn't
be recognized at all by AWS and AWS
would just default to false in this case
so even if your code seemingly sets your
root file systems to read only uh they
wouldn't actually be read only and you
would have no way to know unless you go
in to AWS and look at the actual
configuration that it results in that's
quite scary but nowadays by having a
typed wrapper on top of it the developer
would immediately see this
error so let's look at some pros and
cons from our experience using CDK for
Terraform the first is that for the
people in this room who work as platform
engineers uh object-oriented programming
kind of helps with writing modules it's
a lot easier to maintain um I gave some
examples of inheritance earlier you can
also add methods to add further
configuration later uh so this is really
helpful for breaking cycles between
different modules for instance you might
have some VP
some some database module and then some

allow ingress between them and it's a
bit unintuitive how you would be able to

to break it out into a third module that
creates the link between the two uh
using object orientation you could just
add a method uh which you can call later
called add ingress or something along
that lines
it also allows you to add more degrees
of abstraction so there's no need to
configure backends if you don't want the

backends if you're looking to do that um
and it's truly like being able to add

there are so many configuration options

uh one common thing that has happened at

this would offload the cloud
